nodes.label: Social connection
nodes.summary: Social connection reduces all-cause mortality by ~50% (Holt-Lunstad et al. 2010, 300K+ participants). Neural mechanism: social interaction → oxytocin → VTA dopamine → nucleus accumbens → reward loop.

nodes.label: social interaction
nodes.summary: Social interaction reduces mortality by 50% (meta-analysis, 300k+ participants). Triggers oxytocin→VTA dopamine→nucleus accumbens pathway, creating reward feedback loop that reinforces approach behavior.

nodes.label: All-cause mortality
nodes.summary: All-cause mortality reduced by ~50% through social connection according to meta-analysis of 148 studies with 300,000+ participants (Holt-Lunstad et al. 2010). Effect comparable to quitting smoking.

nodes.label: Meta-analytic evidence
nodes.summary: Meta-analytic evidence supporting dopamine-serotonin opposing effects on decision-making, learning, and cognitive processing. Referenced as PMC12159863. Establishes dopamine as accelerator for reward-seeking and serotonin as brake promoting patience.

nodes.label: Romantic love
nodes.summary: Near-universal human phenomenon found in 147 of 166 cultures (88.5%). Activates dopaminergic reward pathways (VTA, caudate nucleus) consistently across cultures. Evolved as mammalian courtship system to focus mating energy on preferred partners.

nodes.label: social isolation
nodes.summary: Social isolation inhibits oxytocin neuron activity, disrupting the VTA dopamine pathway. Lack of social connection increases all-cause mortality by ~50% (meta-analysis of 148 studies, 300k+ participants).

nodes.label: Heart-brain coupling
nodes.summary: Heart rate variability synchronizes with brain waves through vagal mechanisms. Cardiac sympathovagal activity initiates brain responses. High-frequency HRV couples with delta, theta, alpha, beta, gamma bands. RSA quantifies vagal activity.

nodes.label: Ethnographic evidence
nodes.summary: Research methodology used by Jankowiak & Fischer (1992) to analyze romantic love across 166 cultures, finding evidence in 147 cultures (88.5%). Published in Ethnology journal (JSTOR 3773618).

nodes.label: Biosocial model
nodes.summary: Biosocial model explains romantic love as universal biological capacity with culturally variable expression. Developed by de Munck (PMC12118770), combines evolutionary mechanisms with social factors.

nodes.label: Mammalian courtship attraction system
nodes.summary: Evolutionary system where romantic love evolved as mammalian courtship attraction to focus mating energy on preferred partners. Activates dopamine reward pathways (VTA, caudate nucleus) universally across cultures. Found in 147 of 166 cultures studied.

nodes.label: Long-term relationships
nodes.summary: Romantic love universally valued for long-term relationships across 175 countries (2025 study, 117K participants). Social connection reduces mortality 50% via oxytocin-dopamine pathways. Heart-brain coupling enhances emotion regulation.

nodes.label: de Munck biosocial model
nodes.summary: Biosocial model explaining romantic love as universal biological capacity with culturally variable expression. Referenced in PMC12118770 study on cross-cultural romantic love patterns.

nodes.label: Human phenomenon
nodes.summary: Universal human phenomena include social connection (reduces mortality 50%, comparable to quitting smoking), romantic love (found in 147/166 cultures, activates dopamine pathways), and neurochemical systems where dopamine drives reward-seeking while serotonin promotes patience and long-term think...

nodes.label: Evolutionary mechanism
nodes.summary: Evolutionary mechanisms explain romantic love as mammalian courtship system for focusing mating energy on preferred partners, social connection's 50% mortality reduction through oxytocin-dopamine pathways creating reward loops.

nodes.label: Cultural variation
nodes.summary: Cultural variation in romantic love: Nuclear family systems value it more; higher female status correlates with emphasis; modernization increases importance; lower SES values it MORE as commitment device.

nodes.label: cognitive processing
nodes.summary: Dopamine acts as accelerator promoting immediate action and reward-seeking, while serotonin functions as brake promoting patience and long-term thinking in cognitive processing (Stanford 2024).

nodes.label: oxytocin
nodes.summary: Oxytocin directly modulates dopamine neurons in VTA, increases dopamine release in nucleus accumbens during social interactions. Creates positive feedback loop: social connection → oxytocin release → reward pathway activation → approach behavior. Social isolation inhibits oxytocin neuron activity.

nodes.label: neural mechanism
nodes.summary: Neural mechanisms include: social connection → oxytocin → VTA dopamine → nucleus accumbens reward loop; dopamine accelerates reward-seeking while serotonin provides inhibitory brake; heart rate variability couples with brain waves via vagal pathways; romantic love activates dopamine reward pathwa...

nodes.label: positive feedback loop
nodes.summary: Neurobiological mechanism where social interaction triggers oxytocin release → VTA dopamine neurons → nucleus accumbens reward → approach behavior → more social interaction, creating self-reinforcing cycle.

nodes.label: serotonin
nodes.summary: Neurotransmitter that functions as a "brake" in decision-making, promoting patience and long-term thinking. Creates inhibitory "wait" signals and promotes learning from punishments. Has opposing effects to dopamine in cognitive processing.

nodes.label: Nuclear family systems
nodes.summary: Family structure where nuclear family systems value romantic love more highly than other family structures. Cultural organization pattern that correlates with increased emphasis on romantic love in relationships.

nodes.label: Commitment device
nodes.summary: Economic concept where individuals with lower socioeconomic status use romantic love as a commitment device to manage economic vulnerability in relationships.

nodes.label: neuroscience
nodes.summary: Social connection reduces mortality ~50% via oxytocin→VTA dopamine→nucleus accumbens pathway. Dopamine accelerates reward-seeking, serotonin brakes for patience. HRV syncs with brain waves through vagal mechanisms. Romantic love shows universal dopaminergic activation across cultures.

nodes.label: oxytocin neuron activity
nodes.summary: Oxytocin neurons directly modulate VTA dopamine neurons, increasing dopamine release in nucleus accumbens during social interaction. Social isolation inhibits oxytocin neuron activity, disrupting the reward pathway.

nodes.label: Brain oscillations
nodes.summary: Brain oscillations couple with heart rate variability through vagal mechanisms across delta, theta, alpha, beta, and gamma bands. High-frequency HRV shows stronger coupling with brain waves via cardiac sympathovagal activity.

nodes.label: oxytocin release
nodes.summary: Oxytocin release occurs during social interactions and directly modulates dopamine neurons in VTA, increasing dopamine release in nucleus accumbens to create rewarding feelings and promote approach behavior through positive feedback loop.

nodes.label: approach behavior
nodes.summary: Approach behavior is promoted by dopamine acting as accelerator for reward-seeking. Dopamine signals when outcomes exceed expectations, promoting immediate action. Social interactions trigger oxytocin → VTA dopamine → nucleus accumbens → reward → approach behavior in positive feedback loop.

nodes.label: long-term thinking
nodes.summary: Serotonin acts as a brake that promotes long-term thinking and patience by creating inhibitory "wait" signals, opposing dopamine's immediate action-promoting effects. Established by Stanford 2024 study.

nodes.label: Lower socioeconomic status individuals
nodes.summary: Lower SES individuals value romantic love MORE than higher SES groups, using it as commitment device for economic vulnerability according to cross-cultural study of 117,293 participants across 175 countries.

nodes.label: Emotion regulation
nodes.summary: Higher respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA) improves emotion regulation through myelinated vagal activity. Serotonin acts as brake promoting patience and long-term thinking in decision-making processes.

nodes.label: Brain waves
nodes.summary: Brain waves synchronize with heart rate variability through vagal mechanisms. Coupling occurs across delta, theta, alpha, beta, and gamma bands. Cardiac sympathovagal activity initiates functional brain responses.

nodes.label: Jankowiak & Fischer study
nodes.summary: 1992 ethnographic study published in Ethnology (JSTOR 3773618) that examined 166 cultures and found evidence of romantic love in 147 cultures (88.5%), demonstrating romantic love as a near-universal human phenomenon rather than Western invention.

nodes.label: Nature
nodes.summary: Scientific journal that published Stanford 2024 study on dopamine and serotonin's opposing effects on decision-making, learning, and cognitive processing.

nodes.label: Effect size
nodes.summary: Effect size of social connection on mortality comparable to quitting smoking - approximately 50% reduction in all-cause mortality (meta-analysis of 148 studies, 300,000+ participants)

nodes.label: 2025 cross-cultural study
nodes.summary: 2025 cross-cultural study (PMC11836147) with 117,293 participants across 175 countries confirmed romantic love is universally valued for long-term relationships, supporting romantic love as near-universal human phenomenon.

nodes.label: Holt-Lunstad et al. 2010
nodes.summary: Meta-analysis published in PLoS Medicine analyzing 148 studies with 300,000+ participants. Found social connection reduces all-cause mortality by ~50%, effect comparable to quitting smoking.

nodes.label: structural optimism
nodes.summary: Social connection reduces mortality by 50% (meta-analysis of 148 studies). Neural pathway: social interaction → oxytocin → dopamine release in nucleus accumbens → reward feedback loop, providing biological basis for structural optimism.

nodes.label: Heart rate variability
nodes.summary: Heart rate variability synchronizes with brain waves through vagal mechanisms. High-frequency HRV shows stronger coupling with brain oscillations across delta, theta, alpha, beta, and gamma bands. Respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA) quantifies myelinated vagal activity - higher RSA improves emotio...

nodes.label: Meta-analysis
nodes.summary: Meta-analysis by Holt-Lunstad et al. 2010 in PLoS Medicine analyzed 148 studies with 300,000+ participants. Found social connection reduces all-cause mortality by 50%, effect comparable to quitting smoking.

nodes.label: Ethnology journal
nodes.summary: Academic journal that published Jankowiak & Fischer 1992 study finding romantic love in 147 of 166 cultures (88.5%) using ethnographic evidence. Source reference: JSTOR 3773618.

nodes.label: Fisher neuroscience study
nodes.summary: Fisher neuroscience study (PMC1764845) found consistent dopaminergic activation patterns in VTA and caudate nucleus across culturally diverse individuals experiencing romantic love, supporting universality of love mechanisms.

nodes.label: Smoking cessation
nodes.summary: Meta-analysis of 148 studies (300,000+ participants) shows social connection reduces mortality by ~50%, with effect size comparable to quitting smoking (Holt-Lunstad et al. 2010).

nodes.label: dopamine release
nodes.summary: Neurotransmitter that acts as accelerator for reward-seeking behavior, signals when outcomes exceed expectations, promotes approach behavior. Released in nucleus accumbens through oxytocin-VTA pathway during social interaction and romantic love via VTA-caudate nucleus activation.

nodes.label: nucleus accumbens
nodes.summary: Brain region where dopamine is released during social interactions. Part of reward pathway: oxytocin → VTA dopamine neurons → nucleus accumbens → reward/approach behavior. Key target for dopamine-mediated reward processing.

nodes.label: dopamine
nodes.summary: Neurotransmitter that acts as accelerator for reward-seeking behavior, signals when outcomes exceed expectations, promotes immediate action and approach behavior. Has opposing effects to serotonin in decision-making and learning. Released in nucleus accumbens through oxytocin-VTA pathway during s...

nodes.label: Vagal mechanisms
nodes.summary: Vagal mechanisms involve myelinated vagal activity that couples heart rate variability with brain oscillations across delta, theta, alpha, beta, and gamma bands. Higher respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA) improves emotion regulation.

nodes.label: learning
nodes.summary: Learning is influenced by dopamine and serotonin neurotransmitters with opposing effects. Dopamine accelerates reward-seeking and signals when outcomes exceed expectations. Serotonin acts as brake promoting patience and learning from punishments.

nodes.label: Theta band
nodes.summary: Brain oscillation frequency band that shows coupling with heart rate variability through vagal mechanisms. Part of heart-brain synchronization across delta, theta, alpha, beta, and gamma bands.

nodes.label: PMC11836147
nodes.summary: 2025 cross-cultural study with 117,293 participants across 175 countries confirming romantic love is universally valued for long-term relationships, supporting that romantic love is not a Western invention.

nodes.label: Myelinated vagal activity
nodes.summary: Myelinated vagal activity quantified through Respiratory Sinus Arrhythmia (RSA). Higher RSA correlates with improved emotion regulation and stronger heart-brain coupling across brain wave frequencies.

nodes.label: PMC12159863
nodes.summary: PMC12159863 is a meta-analytic study providing evidence for opposing effects of dopamine and serotonin on decision-making, learning, and cognitive processing.

nodes.label: Stanford 2024 study
nodes.summary: Stanford 2024 study published in Nature demonstrates dopamine acts as accelerator for reward-seeking while serotonin functions as brake promoting patience and long-term thinking in decision-making.

nodes.label: reward-seeking behavior
nodes.summary: Dopamine acts as accelerator for reward-seeking behavior, promoting immediate action and approach behavior when outcomes exceed expectations. Established neuroscience mechanism.

nodes.label: Frontiers Behavioral Neuroscience
nodes.summary: Academic journal that published 2025 research on heart rate variability synchronization with brain waves through vagal mechanisms and respiratory sinus arrhythmia as index of vagal activity.

nodes.label: decision-making
nodes.summary: Dopamine acts as accelerator for reward-seeking and approach behavior in decision-making, while serotonin functions as brake promoting patience and long-term thinking. These neurotransmitters have opposing effects on cognitive processing and learning mechanisms.

nodes.label: PMC1764845
nodes.summary: Fisher et al. neuroscience study showing consistent dopaminergic activation patterns (VTA, caudate nucleus) across culturally diverse individuals experiencing romantic love

nodes.label: JSTOR
nodes.summary: JSTOR is an academic database that hosts scholarly articles. Referenced as source for Jankowiak & Fischer 1992 study on romantic love across cultures (JSTOR 3773618).

nodes.label: PLoS Medicine
nodes.summary: Academic journal that published Holt-Lunstad et al. 2010 meta-analysis of 148 studies showing social connection reduces mortality by 50% (effect comparable to quitting smoking).

nodes.label: Caudate nucleus
nodes.summary: Brain region that shows consistent dopaminergic activation patterns across culturally diverse individuals experiencing romantic love. Part of reward pathways involved in love's neural mechanisms.

nodes.label: High-frequency HRV
nodes.summary: High-frequency HRV shows stronger coupling with brain oscillations across delta, theta, alpha, beta, and gamma bands through vagal mechanisms. Part of heart-brain coupling research with strong evidence (PNAS 2022).

nodes.label: PMC12118770
nodes.summary: PMC12118770: de Munck biosocial model study on romantic love. Proposes that romantic love represents universal biological capacity with culturally variable expression patterns across societies.

nodes.label: Cardiac sympathovagal activity
nodes.summary: Cardiac sympathovagal activity initiates functional brain responses and shows coupling with brain oscillations across delta, theta, alpha, beta, and gamma bands through vagal mechanisms.

nodes.label: Economic vulnerability
nodes.summary: Lower socioeconomic status individuals value romantic love MORE than higher SES groups. Romantic love serves as commitment device for those facing economic vulnerability, providing stability in uncertain financial circumstances.

nodes.label: PNAS
nodes.summary: PNAS (Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences) published 2022 research on heart-brain coupling, showing cardiac sympathovagal activity initiates brain responses and HRV synchronizes with brain oscillations.

nodes.label: Dopaminergic activation patterns
nodes.summary: Consistent dopaminergic activation patterns occur in VTA and caudate nucleus across culturally diverse individuals experiencing romantic love. Dopamine acts as accelerator for reward-seeking, signaling when outcomes exceed expectations and promoting approach behavior.

nodes.label: ventral tegmental area
nodes.summary: Brain region containing dopamine neurons modulated by oxytocin during social interactions. Releases dopamine to nucleus accumbens creating reward sensation. Shows consistent activation patterns across cultures in romantic love studies.

nodes.label: reward
nodes.summary: Dopamine acts as accelerator for reward-seeking behavior, signaling when outcomes exceed expectations. Social connection activates oxytocin → VTA dopamine → nucleus accumbens reward pathway.

nodes.label: dopamine neurons
nodes.summary: Dopamine neurons in VTA modulated by oxytocin during social interaction, release dopamine in nucleus accumbens creating reward signals. Act as accelerator for reward-seeking, signal when outcomes exceed expectations, promote approach behavior. Part of social connection feedback loop.

nodes.label: Gamma band
nodes.summary: Brain wave frequency band that shows coupling with heart rate variability through vagal mechanisms. Part of multi-band heart-brain synchronization including delta, theta, alpha, and beta waves.

nodes.label: Western invention
nodes.summary: Romantic love is NOT a Western invention. Research across 147-166 cultures shows romantic love exists in 88.5% of societies worldwide, with universal neural patterns and evolutionary origins as a mammalian courtship system.

nodes.label: Respiratory sinus arrhythmia
nodes.summary: Respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA) is a quantifiable index of myelinated vagal activity. Higher RSA levels are associated with improved emotion regulation and heart-brain coupling mechanisms.

nodes.label: Alpha band
nodes.summary: Alpha band is one of the brain wave frequency ranges that shows coupling with heart rate variability through vagal mechanisms, as part of heart-brain synchronization across multiple frequency bands.

nodes.label: VTA dopamine neurons
nodes.summary: Dopamine neurons in ventral tegmental area (VTA) that are directly modulated by oxytocin, release dopamine in nucleus accumbens during social interactions, creating reward signals and positive feedback loops for social behavior.

nodes.label: Beta band
nodes.summary: Beta band brain waves couple with heart rate variability through vagal mechanisms, showing synchronization across delta, theta, alpha, beta, and gamma frequency bands in heart-brain coupling research.

nodes.label: Modernization
nodes.summary: Modernization increases the cultural importance and emphasis on romantic love in societies, part of broader social evolution patterns affecting relationship values and cultural norms.

nodes.label: Delta band
nodes.summary: Delta band is one of the brain wave frequencies that shows coupling with heart rate variability through vagal mechanisms, as part of heart-brain synchronization research.

nodes.label: Female status
nodes.summary: Higher female status correlates with romantic love emphasis in cultures. Cultural factor that influences how societies value and express romantic attraction patterns.
